newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine bonds sustain gains, subdued activity.
newsitem.headline: Argentine bonds sustain gains, subdued activity.

text.p: Argentine bonds finished higher again Wednesday, as Tuesday's well received treasury bill auction continued to sustain the recent strong market tone.
"The market continued to be sustained today," said a trader at a foreign bank. Activity was light, however, reflecting the slowdown in U.S. Treasuries ahead of Thursday's 30-year bond sale.
Argentina's FRB Brady bond due 2005 rose 1/4 to 91-1/2, while the dollar-denominated Bocon Previsional 2 due 2001 rose $0.17 to 126.20.
"The Letes auction gave a clear sign of confidence in the market," said another trader.
Argentina auctioned 250 million pesos of 91-day bills at a cut-off yield of 6.10 percent and $250 million of 182-day bills at 6.09 percent. Both rates were much lower than expected.
Traders said apart from the debt auction in the U.S. on Thursday, the market was turning its focus Argentina's sale Tuesday of $500 million in two year Bonte treasury bonds.
In the money markets, call money rates rose to 6.13 percent from 5.88 percent.
